title: 114_hr4060
content: The Act titled "Imperial Valley Desert Conservation and Recreation Act of 2015" is about land conveyance in Anza-Borrego Desert State Park, California. The Secretary will convey approximately 934 acres of public lands in San Diego County, California to the State for inclusion in Anza-Borrego Desert State Park. The conveyance will occur after the termination of all mining claims related to the parcel, and the State will manage the land according to specified provisions. The State will manage approximately 934 acres of public lands in San Diego County, California, conveyed by the Secretary for inclusion in Anza-Borrego Desert State Park. The parcel is withdrawn from various forms of entry and disposal under different laws, and if the State fails to manage it according to specified provisions, the land will revert to the Secretary to be managed as a Wilderness Study Area. SEC. 3. Land conveyance, Holtville Airport, Imperial County, California. The Secretary of Transportation will consider a conveyance request from Imperial County, California for approximately 3,500 acres of Federal land near the Imperial County Holtville Airport to allow for airport expansion. The Secretary will segregate the land and prohibit its appropriation until certain conditions are met. The notice of realty action terminates the application, and a document of conveyance for the parcel is published. SEC. 4. VINAGRE WASH SPECIAL MANAGEMENT AREA. The Vinagre Wash Special Management Area is established in the State, to be managed by the El Centro Field Office and the Yuma Field Office of the Bureau of Land Management. The term "Management Area" refers to this specific area, and the term "map" refers to a map prepared for this area in 2015. The term "public lands" is defined as per the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976. The Vinagre Wash Special Management Area, managed by the El Centro and Yuma Field Offices of the Bureau of Land Management, aims to conserve and protect the plants, wildlife, and various resources within its boundaries in Imperial County, California, covering approximately 81,880 acres. A map and legal description will be provided within three years of enactment. The Secretary will submit a map and legal description of the Vinagre Wash Special Management Area to the House and Senate Committees within three years of enactment. The submitted map will have the same legal force as the Act, with the Secretary allowed to correct any errors. Copies of the map will be available for public inspection. The Secretary will allow various activities in the Management Area, such as hiking, camping, hunting, and sightseeing, along with the use of motorized vehicles, mountain bikes, and horses on designated routes. These activities must align with the purpose of the area, ensure public health and safety, and comply with applicable laws. The use of off-highway vehicles is permitted on designated routes in the Management Area, with the Secretary having the authority to temporarily close or reroute routes for various reasons such as resource damage, protection of tribal cultural resources, and public safety concerns. During a 3-year period, the Secretary can accept public petitions for additional off-highway vehicle routes in the Management Area and may designate routes that offer unique recreational opportunities and align with the area's purposes. The Management Area is withdrawn from various activities under public land laws, mining laws, and laws related to minerals and energy. No protective buffer zone is created around the Management Area, and activities outside the area permitted by other laws are not restricted. The Management Area is withdrawn from certain activities under public land, mining, and energy laws. The Secretary ensures visitors have access to designated routes through signage, maps, and restoration efforts. Stewardship program development involves consultation with Indian tribes and interested parties. The Secretary will develop a program for monitoring and stewardship of the Management Area to minimize environmental impacts and prevent resource damage from recreational use. This includes volunteer assistance with route signage, restoration of closed routes, protection of resources, and recreation education. Additionally, within 2 years of the Act's enactment, a tribal cultural resources survey will be conducted in consultation with the Quechan Indian Nation. The Secretary will consult with the Quechan Indian Nation and other tribes on the tribal cultural resources survey. The public lands in the Management Area will be managed to preserve wilderness character for potential inclusion in the National Wilderness Preservation System. This includes approximately 10,860 acres of land known as the "Indian Pass Additions." The Secretary will manage public lands, including approximately 17,250 acres known as "Milpitas Wash Potential Wilderness," 11,840 acres as "Buzzards Peak Potential Wilderness," and 9,350 acres as "Palo Verde Mountains Potential Wilderness." Military use will be in line with the Wilderness Act, with potential Navy authorization. The Secretary of the Navy will manage public lands for Naval Special Warfare Tactical Training, including long-range small unit training, vehicle concealment, and sustainment training. Prohibited uses on the public lands include permanent roads and commercial enterprises. Mechanized vehicles and temporary roads are only allowed for land administration and public safety. The public lands covered by this section will eventually be designated as wilderness. The public lands managed by the Secretary of the Navy for Naval Special Warfare Tactical Training will eventually be designated as wilderness, either as part of an existing area or as a new component of the National Wilderness Preservation System. The designation will occur after all incompatible activities on the Federal land have ceased. The California Desert Protection Act of 1994 designates specific areas as wilderness, including Milpitas Wash, Buzzard Peak, and incorporating land into the Palo Verde Mountains Wilderness. The California Desert Protection Act of 1994 designates wilderness areas to be administered by the Secretary in accordance with the Wilderness Act. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior, and "State" refers to the State of California.
